title: 104_hr3992
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" and establishes the Medicare Commission. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program, known as the Commission, is established with 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. Members can be from the executive branch, Senate, or private citizens, with a limit on political party representation. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and the Speaker of the House. Members can be from the executive branch, Senate, House of Representatives, or private citizens, with limits on political party representation. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and the Speaker of the House. Members are selected with limits on political party representation and appointments must be made within 3 months of the enactment of the Act. The members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairman, a majority of members constitute a quorum, and a lesser number can hold hearings. The Commission shall hold its first meeting, meet at the call of the Chairman, have a majority of members as a quorum, and select a Chairman from among its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifying potential threats to their solvency, analyzing solutions to ensure financial integrity, and providing recommendations to relevant authorities. The Commission is responsible for reviewing the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds and providing recommendations to preserve their long-term solvency to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the President, and Congress. The term "Medicare trust funds" refers to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission must submit its report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. The Commission must submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional leaders will develop legislation based on the recommendations in the report to ensure the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds. Legislation must be introduced in the Senate and House of Representatives within 3 months of the report submission to ensure Medicare trust funds' long-term solvency. If not voted upon within 3 months in the House, the legislation will receive privileged consideration. Legislation introduced in the House and Senate must be voted upon within 3 months. If not voted upon in the House, the legislation will receive privileged consideration. Legislation introduced in the Senate must be voted upon within 3 months. If not voted upon, any committee to which the legislation has been referred will be discharged, and a motion to proceed to consideration of the legislation will be privileged. If legislation is not considered and approved or disapproved, a vote on endorsing commission recommendations will take place. Legislation introduced in the Senate must be voted upon within 3 months. If not voted upon, a motion to consider a joint resolution endorsing commission recommendations will be privileged. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Act addresses personnel matters related to the Commission. The Commission members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay, but they are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission members who are not federal government officers or employees are allowed travel expenses for services performed, including per diem, at rates authorized for agency employees. The Chairman can appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman may determine their compensation without adhering to specific pay regulations. The Commission can appoint personnel without following civil service laws or pay regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual pay for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Funding for the Commission's expenses will come from funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
